description.narrative:
The program seeks to address and contribute to solutions to the following specific problems: - Weak capacity for local governance in regions and little dialogue between legislative, executive, judiciary, political parties and civil society. Centralised system of governance and low level of devolution to the states, regions and self-administered zones. - Low level of autonomy and capacities inself-administered zones, due to continued dependence under respective State Administrations. - Slow spread of democratisation process to local administrations, and persistence of attitudes and behaviours shaped by the long era of dictatorship, often leading to top-down and autocratic leadership, lack of practise of sharing of information, and unfamiliarity with dialogue and constructive conflict resolution. - Frail civil society with little experience of democratic principles or dialogue and peaceful conflict resolution with state actors, including local administrations. - Low levels of inclusion of women and youth in governance and low prioritisationof female participation in the domestic agenda.
Project Outcomes:
1. By the end of the program June 2014, 5 basic capacity building workshops on local governance, challenges of decentralisation and federalism, dialogue and democratic culture, and peace buildingwill have enhanced the capacity and awareness level of 350 participants from the Region and Self-Administered Zone levels, CSO’s.
2: By June 2014, because there is openness and space for feedback, the program will have secured the interest and active participation that will have led to an Iimproved dialogue and cooperation between key local government, parliamentarians and civil society.
3: By the end of June 2014, 2 interregional meetings attended by 30 selected participants from the program including study tours, internships, web-based forum, and joint advocacy campaigns will have cultivated a wider network between selected regions.

participating-org.narrative: The Tampadipa Institute is a Myanmar national institute working on policy advocacy and capacity building since 2006. It has been lobbying within the areas of health care (particularly HIV/AIDS), conflict resolution, agriculture and rural development andforeign relations, wherein it was the first domestic voice for the lifting of sanctions. It has also facilitated food security activities in the post-cyclone Nargis recovery period. Civic and political education courses have been delivered to civil society in Sagaing, Shan, Kayin, Kachin and northern Shan states At present, the institute is facilitating inputs for bodies of the new state, particularly the Parliament, with a view to institution building and lobbying. As the first multi-party Parliament in Myanmar in 49 years gets going, Tampadipa is playing a pivotal part in establishing the critical links between parliamentarians and civil society. As part of the Land Core Group, important inputs have been provided to leading MPs on land issues.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to social and political participation
